banner.title: TP WorkLife 10/12
banner.mainContentHeadline: The podcast where science meets business
banner.mainContent: From fixing meetings to finding a mentor, get new insights to help you enjoy your time at work and thrive in your career.

videoData.title: Are our cultural narratives killing sharks?
videoData.socialTitle: Are our cultural narratives killing sharks?

nodes.whoTheyAre: From modest beginnings as a movie grip in 1978, and has become an internationally acclaimed, award-winning writer, producer, director, cinematographer, and a full member of the Television Academy. PCD has filmed on six continents and thrives in all spheres of production, from aerial to undersea. Credits include HBO Documentaries, Animal Planet, PBS, The Amazing Race, Travel Channel, and The Discovery Channel. His underwater documentaries have aired all over the world, and he is internationally published. Over the past 20 years, Paul has presented over 100 seminars, workshops and film festivals around the world. He lives in the Virgin Islands.

videoData.description: Why do our cultural narratives about sharks center around the misguided notion that they're villainous or mindless killing machines? In this passionate talk, filmmaker Paul Cater Deaton does some shark-related myth-busting and argues that we need to come up with some fact-based stories to help rehabilitate the image of these near-extinct animals.
videoData.socialDescription: Why do our cultural narratives about sharks center around the misguided notion that they're villainous or mindless killing machines? In this passionate talk, filmmaker Paul Cater Deaton does some shark-related myth-busting and argues that we need to come up with some fact-based stories to help rehabilitate the image of these near-extinct animals.
